pullRequest.body:
Add three simple lemmas to the AnalyticAt namespace, to simplify working with orders of analytic functions.

These lemmas are used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [cb6bf08993](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20813/commits/cb6bf08993ab8fcdebcfd2ef039120983c2d665e)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ order_eq_zero_iff`
`+ order_neq_top_iff`
`+ zero_if_order_toNat_eq_zero`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

@grunweg @loefflerd Thanks for taking the time to look at this. I implemented all your suggestions.

@loefflerd Dear David, great seeing you here. I hope you are doing as well as we are.
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.

One last thing, then this is good to go.
maintainer delegate

Thanks for your PR! I happened to have some time, so took a look. I have a few comments - some are just about style/should be easy to address. A few are about deeper aspects (like library design); if you'd like help with these, don't hesitate to ask.
This looks good to me, the new lemmas will certainly add usability. I left a couple of very minor comments.

One last thing, then this is good to go.
maintainer delegate
This docstring is missing an object, e.g. "iff it locally looks".
Done.
This `rfl` proof ought to exist somewhere. Can you replace it by the right `rw` lemma (or add that, if missing)?
Found it an added it.

You can definitely compress this line, by making `f` part of the exact.

You can also write it as `exact fun hz \mapsto  ⟨f, hf, hz, by simp⟩` (similarly for the line above);
then you could combine this into one big
```
exact ⟨fun  ⟨g, _, _, hg⟩ \mapsto by simpa [Eventually.self_of_nhds hg],
  fun hz \mapsto ⟨f, hf, hz, by simp⟩
```
with \mapsto replaced by the corresponding symbol.

I think the first suggestion is definitely better. This second one might be a matter of taste. (If you think that "this proof is mathematically trivial", I'd say you can golf it down all the way. If not, using constructor is fine.)
Implemented following your suggestion #1.

In general, `erw` is a code smell: usually it indicates something sub-optimal.
Can you tell what `rw`s you need to use? (Maybe there are even some missing API lemmas.)

If you get stuck, feel free to ask for help here or on zulip.

The issue is that the lemma `order_neq_top_iff` speaks about `f =ᶠ[𝓝 z₀]  F` while the theorem `order_eq_nat_iff` speaks about `∀ᶠ (z : 𝕜) in 𝓝 z₀, f z = F z`. These two statements are definitionally equal (that´s the definition of `EventuallyEq`) but the `rw` and `simp_rw` tactics are not able to make the match. I have replaced the offending line by `unfold EventuallyEq; rw [← hf.order_eq_nat_iff]`, but one could think about adding a theorem `EventuallyEq.def` that can be used with `rw`. Please let me know if you want me to add that.
Does `rw [EventuallyEq]` work here?
Implemented, following David's suggestion below.

Purely aesthetic question: does the theorem statement still fit on the same line?
(I'd consider that slightly nicer. This is a matter of taste, i.e. optional for you to follow.)
It does. Changed following your suggestion.
I think the usual mathilb library style is to put each tactic on a new line (rather than using "`;`").
Reformatted following your suggestion.

It seems my earlier suggestion of `rw [EventuallyEq]` doesn't work, because `rw` can't see inside the `∃ g` binder; but `simp_rw` or `simp only` works. One can golf the proof down to the following:
```suggestion
  simp only [← ENat.coe_toNat_eq_self, Eq.comm, EventuallyEq, ← hf.order_eq_nat_iff]
```

This is a terminal simp (i.e., the `simp` tactic to close a goal). In general, it's more robust to not "squeeze" it, i.e. just use `simp` or `simp [lemmas]` if possible --- unless there's a performance reason.

```suggestion
  simp [← ENat.coe_toNat_eq_self, Eq.comm, EventuallyEq, ← hf.order_eq_nat_iff]
Understood. I hope I will remember this next time.

This is now a non-terminal simp: in general, we prefer to avoid these. On the other hand, `tauto` is a pretty robust tactic, so in this case, I'd say it's fine. (You can use the `flexible` linter to check: place `set_option linter.flexible true` above your lemma; no warnings means it's fine.)
Ok. I understand that I don't need to do anything here, but remember for next time to avoid those.

pullRequest.title: feat: add lemmas for working with orders of analytic functions
